Petition of Richard S. Thomas and Others to U.S. Congress, [6 December 1847 - 3 March

1849],1 The undersigned, citizens and legal voters of the County ofCassand State ofIllinois, would respectfully represent, in reference to the lands granted by the United States

to the State of Illinois, for the use of the inhabitants of the townships hereinafter

mentioned, for the use of schools, as follows, viz.2 The School lands of township nineteen North, of Range Eleven W. of 3 P. M3^also all except 200 acres, being (Section 16) of Township 17 North of Range 8 West

of the 3dP. M^–4Also the School lands (being Section 16) of township Seventeen North, of Range twelve

W. of 3dP. M–5also the school lands (being Section 16) of township Eighteen North, of Range nine

West of the 3dP. M–6and also, all except two hundred and thirty acres, of the school lands, (being Section

16) of township Eighteen North, of Range ten West of the 3dP. M,7^also all except 400 acres of the school lands (being Sec 16) of Township 18 Range 11 West–8^are worthless and therefore wholly unsaleable, and said lands are not only worth

less now, but are so very poor in quality that they must continue so permanently.

So that the inhabitants of said townships can never realize a School fund from said

worthless lands– Each of said townships Contains a considerable number of inhabitants,

& has no other school lands The undersigned would further represent, that fractional township, Seventeen North,

of Range thirteen W. of the 3dP. M. contains no section numbered Sixteen, and no school lands whatever have ever been

assigned to said^fractional^township in lieu of Section Sixteen– So that said fractional township has no school

lands– but contains near one hundred inhabitants.9 In consideration of which premises, the undersigned would respectfully pray that a

law be passed by Congress authorizing the selection of other lands^for said fractional township &^belonging to the United States & situated in the state of Illinois,^for said fractional township & also^in lieu of said worthless lands– the lands so to be selected to be granted by the

United States to the state of Illinois for the use of the inhabitants of said townships

respectively, for the use of schools– And as in duty bound &c

footnotes.text:
1On the back side of this handwritten petition, Abraham Lincoln authored and signed
                  one instance of docketing. It is unclear when and if Lincoln presented this petition
                  to the U.S. House of Representatives.

2TheLand Ordinance of 1785reserved the sixteenth section of each full thirty-six-section township to support
                  public schools within the township.  Upon Illinois’ admission as a state in 1818,
                  Congress granted to every  township in the state the proceeds of the sale of land
                  in each township’s Section 16 for the use of schools. This money became known as the
                  “common school fund.”“An Act to Enable the People of the Illinois Territory to Form a Constitution and
                     State Government, and for the Admission of Such State into the Union on an Equal Footing
                     with the Original States,” 18 April 1818,Statutes at Large of the United States, 3 (1846):428-31; W. L. Pillsbury, “Early Education in Illinois,”Sixteenth Biennial Report of the Superintendent of Public Instruction of the State
                        of Illinois(Springfield, IL: H. W. Rokker, 1886), 106-7.

3This land was located in a bend of theSangamon Rivernear its confluence with theIllinois River, and was bisected by a large slough.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois(W. R. Brink, 1874),https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.

4This land was located north of Ashland, on the border of Cass andMenardcounties.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.

5This section  was located north of Indian Creek in southwestern Cass County.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.

6This section was located southeast of Chandlerville, on the south side of Big Panther
                  Creek, and was bisected by Cox’s Creek.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.

7This land was located south of the Sangamon River in north-central Cass County.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.
8This land was located east ofBeardstown.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.

9This fractional township was located in the extreme southwestern corner of the county,
                  bounded by the Illinois River.Illustrated Atlas Map of Cass County, Illinois,https://www.loc.gov/resource/g4103cm.gla00038/?sp=9&r=0.061,0.202,0.55,0.226,0.
